item.title: By: Lawrence Kaplan
item.dc:creator: Lawrence Kaplan
item.description: There are two translations of The Brothers Ashkenazi, an older one by Maurice Samuel and a newer one by Singer's son.The newer one is slightly abridged. Someone ought to compare the two translations. I remember reading one very interesting chapter in the Samuel translation where a revolutionary is being interrogated by a member the police. It is missing from the newer translation. I enjoyed reading the novel very much, but agree with Avakes that its unremitting negative outlook is a serious artistic blemish. Buddenbrook's, it's not.
item.content:encoded:
There are two translations of The Brothers Ashkenazi, an older one by Maurice Samuel and a newer one by Singer’s son.The newer one is slightly abridged. Someone ought to compare the two translations. I remember reading one very interesting chapter in the Samuel translation where a revolutionary is being interrogated by a member the police. It is missing from the newer translation.
I enjoyed reading the novel very much, but agree with Avakes that its unremitting negative outlook is a serious artistic blemish. Buddenbrook’s, it’s not.

item.title: By: avakesh
item.dc:creator: avakesh
item.description: Look, there were, are and will be all kinds of people out there. To take the vitriolic, ideology driven slanderous portrayal of hassidic society as completely true is just as immature and naive as idealizing it completely. Other books will give you a different protrayal. Singer has an agenda.
